are going to lose their minds.
It's like a pop art reboot of this
classic film.
>> I actually thought maybe the ship had
sailed as far as like doing new material
and uh I was wrong.
We had this up and cominging season that
a lot of it set on the west coast and
quite a bit of it in the Fortnite
version of Los Angeles and we felt well
what better way to celebrate that than
have some sort of partnership with one
of America's greatest directors Quentyn.
>> And I said yeah well that that really
sounds cool. I I think it would be a
wonderful fit for both uh uh the game
world and for the characters. And I
resisted doing it for a very long time.
And I think I I I resisted waiting for
writing for when the time was right.
Well, Fortnite seemed right. Something
more cinematic inside of a much bigger
world. I asked him the question. I'm
like, Quentyn, in all your years of
directing all these amazing movies,
there must have been scenes that you
either had to cut or weren't able to
film because of whatever circumstances.
And he said, well, it's funny you
mentioned that. There's a scene in Kill
Bill that we really, really wanted to
make um called Yuki's Revenge that was
just not possible to film at the time.
And that was really what catalyzed this
piece. When I wrote the first draft of
the script, there was a lost chapter
that frankly I just didn't think we
could pull off. And Yuki has been a
figment of my imagination for over 20
years.
>> For him, the characters are very much
alive and real and exist. And so, in a
way, letting one of his unborn
characters be birthed and come to life
in this way was really exciting. But
I'll be honest, I wouldn't be that
excited just web spinning something that
I would think would be appropriate for a
game. But the idea that this is actually
a chapter from the first movie, but I
was never able to film it, that just
makes it a horse of a different color.
And there's just a legitimacy to it that
I I think can't be denied.
One thing we're really aware of is that
there are a lot of very dedicated Kill
Bill fans out there and I count myself
among them. And even though we want to
integrate the humor and the characters
from Fortnite, we want to make sure that
we still feel authentic to that world
that that Quentyn's created. And that's
why it's so important that we get folks
like Zoe Bell and Uma Thurman involved
because you are asking somebody to sort
of stand as the bride. That's a very
hard thing to do. She has a certain
posture. She has a certain way of
carrying herself that Zoe and Uma know.
>> Playing the bride and just the whole
creation of Kill Bill was probably the
most incredible holistic cinematic
experience of my life. You know, it's
been a long time since I've been the
bride. But it did start coming back. And
I will say with this technology, being
able to watch myself as the bride whilst
I'm moving, I mean, I could literally I
was standing there and I was like, "Oh,
that's I look like me." And then I'd
move a little bit and go, "Ah, there's
the bride."
>> Having Unreal's ability to render
characters in real time is a huge aid,
not only for animators, but performers
as well. They could test certain poses,
try different facial expressions, see
what reads the best for that physicality
that they're trying to convey.
Bringing Miyu Roberts into this
production was great. Her being of the
younger generation that kind of
understands the types of characters that
are in Fortnite and understanding how
that connects to the world of Kill Bill,
meaning she could see how all of those
characters could exist in this world and
then she was able to bring that
performance, that spark,
>> bingo,
>> to Yuki in the Fortnite Quentyn
Tarantino universe.
It's such a new and innovative way to
film something like this because I could
see exactly what my body was doing,
exactly what every prop was doing,
exactly what things were reacting to
within the world. And I didn't have to
think about it because it was right
there. And if I needed to reference it,
I could. And I didn't have to worry too
much about how it would look because I
knew how it would look.
having these guns on set that everyone
knows is completely safe,
but also having it play where you can
see I'm reacting. So, whoever's shooting
the gun is literally training it past me
and it's all happening in real time. The
cars falling apart and you think you
watch it back and you're like, we just
did the whole lot, guys. That was
amazing. You know,
>> when it comes to firing weapons in a
virtual production, it's really
important that they have that visceral
reaction to the prop that they're using,
but also that they know that they're
hitting something. And so, we have, you
know, what we call muzzle report
attached to the end of the weapon, and
that actually registers those shots in
Unreal Engine. And being able to have
her feel like she's firing an actual
weapon is something that we've never
seen on a virtual production set before.
>> We knew that using Unreal Engine was
going to be a key to us getting through
this thing. as quickly as we could.
There's a lot you can do with
composition and camera work on the day
that would have taken a lot more cycles
with boards or with previs.
>> All of these tools are available for
Unreal Engine users. So, we want to
bring this from professionals down to
the the home user and still get that
same level of quality.
>> It's just really cool to see that you
can get a couple of actors out there and
just set your whole piece up there in
real time.
which then led to our shoot in New York
uh in which we had Uma obviously who's
playing the bride and Miyu who's playing
Yuki and our Metahuman team has a
headmounted camera that we had on each
of the actors and so in getting the
voice over we also got facial data from
our actors. So we sort of got a bunch of
things in one shoot that will then feed
our final animation.
>> Quinton is actually a guy who loves
funny moments and the exaggerated
moments. So an animator is bringing a
perspective of how to take the intent of
this performance and be true to that
performance, but there's still an
artistic perspective that is being
translated into the final product. This
was just sort of an all-encompassing
sort of like soul capture. Hi Uma. And
it's so novel to wear the camera on your
head, but I completely forgot about it.
just started to live in the moments of
the scenes we were doing.
>> In about two minutes, there's going to
be an army of police here. So, if you're
going to kill me, now's the time. And
getting to look at the animation and
then imagine how to embody that image
with sound to bring it alive. It was
really a joy. And uh I hope that like
new generations fall in love with it the
way I fell in love with the character.
The future for our combined industries
is you tell stories across both mediums.
You don't only get to see and listen to
a story or watch a story. You also get
to be part of that story and play in
them events. And Unreal Engine and
Fortnite gives you the ability to choose
which way you go. And you can mix these
things up in ways you would have never
thought possible 10 years ago.
Fortnite has this incredible following
that are following it in real time. I
love the idea of millions
of people
watching it all over the planet Earth at
one go.
It's bringing those two authentic worlds
together into one package. And I think
it takes all of these people who have
knowledge of Kill Bill, people who have
knowledge of Fortnite and the characters
that exist there, and bringing those
together and layering them on top of
each other and creating something wholly
new.
